posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
@Greg_Needel or other REV team can you help answer this? Are the brown and blue pairs of network wires on the rio side of the Radio Power Module isolated? Is it safe to connect an ethernet cable with these wires energized with 12vdc?

If so then it would be simple to switch between the new VH-109 radio and the old OpenMesh radio over the summer as teams attend different events with different requirements. The cable that could possibly be providing power to the VH-109 and connecting to the rio could be moved from the VH-109 to the RPM (Rio port) safely. Then add a new network cable between the RPM and OpenMesh radio containing the 18vdc passive POE

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
Corey_Applegate:

The cable that could possibly be providing power to the VH-109 and connecting to the rio could be moved from the VH-109 to the RPM (Rio port) safely. Then add a new network cable between the RPM and OpenMesh radio containing the 18vdc passive POE

What you’re describing just sounds like the standard setup? I’m not sure why you want input from REV. EDIT: I understand what you’re asking now. I wouldn’t recommend that.

If teams are planning on switching between radios, the easy solution is to simply power the VH-109 with the RPM , which was a legal configuration at CMP . While the primary goal of the VH-109’s power regulator is to eliminate the need for an external one (like the RPM ) to eliminate failure points, it was also specifically designed to work with all existing legal methods of powering the OM5P for ease of interoperability.

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
thatnameistaken:

What you’re describing just sounds like the standard setup? I’m not sure why you want input from REV. Regardless, if teams are planning on switching between radios, the easy solution is to simply power the VH-109 with the RPM , which was a legal configuration at CMP . While the primary goal of the VH-109’s power regulator is to eliminate the need for an external one (like the RPM ) to eliminate failure points, it was also specifically designed to work with all existing legal methods of powering the OM5P for ease of interoperability.

sure though we choose to connect both the 12vdc terminals and 12vdc POE for redundancy.

I see you edited the original response. To be clear for other readers I’m proposing injecting 12vdc into the Rev Power Module’s (Rio port) It safe to say the 18vdc coming from the RPM is only on the (Radio Port) brown and blue pairs.  All 8 pins are present on the module but seeing this is a passive injector I again assume these pins are dead ends on the (Rio Port)

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
Corey_Applegate:

sure though we choose to connect both the 12vdc terminals and 12vdc POE for redundancy.

Fair enough, I suppose. I’ve personally never seen a radio powered by an RPM suffer a power failure, but I won’t advise against redundancy.

Corey_Applegate:

It safe to say the 18vdc coming from the RPM is only on the (Radio Port) brown and blue pairs. All 8 pins are present on the module but seeing this is a passive injector I again assume these pins are dead ends on the (Rio Port)

That would be my conclusion as well, though I’d agree with getting confirmation from REV if this is your desired setup.

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
thatnameistaken:

Fair enough, I suppose. I’ve personally never seen a radio powered by an RPM suffer a power failure, but I won’t advise against redundancy.

For clarity for other readers. It is NOT currently possible to have redundant power for the openMesh radio while using the RPM .

Vivid does show the best practice wiring scheme is to use both 12vdc power inputs.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: It is equally not possible to have redundant power to the vivid radio using an RPM , just FYI
